Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Advanced Molecular Architectures for Electronically-Active Radical Polymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The development of new electronic materials is critical to a number of technological fields that range from defense applications to personal electronic devices to biomedical monitoring and drug delivery. This project will develop new kinds of plastic electronic materials that are lightweight, flexible, and stretchable in nature. In particular, it will establish how such polymers can be used in next-generation flexible electronic devices. In addition to having robust mechanical properties these plastics also can be deposited in a manner that is consistent with low-cost production techniques like inkjet printing. Furthermore, these efforts will correlate the mechanical properties of the newly-synthesized materials with electronic properties of plastic materials. In achieving this goal, the project will be able to establish the fundamental design principles that will allow for a new class of plastic conductors to be implemented in a number of energy conversion, energy storage, and biomedical devices, which will aid the nation and individual consumers.

Additionally, this effort will support the training of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students in the realm of fundamental and applied polymer science. In particular, a high school research program will be implemented in order to attract a larger number of students from economically-disadvantaged families to the polymer science field so as to increase the diversity of the upcoming population of scientists and engineers. Also, the general public will have access to these same types of polymer science lessons due to the development of a massive open online course (MOOC) that will be focused on polymer synthesis and application. In this way, the effort presented here will offer significant fundamental polymer science, polymer engineering, and educational impacts that will allow for the advancement of new plastic electronic materials in both the near and long terms.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Electronically-active macromolecules have been of intense investigation for their application in a number of advanced energy conversion and energy storage modules. To date, the majority of the effort regarding these polymeric materials and polymer-based devices has focused on closed-shell polymers containing a rather high degree of conjugation along their macromolecular backbones. Recently, however, a new class of oxidation-reduction-active (redox-active), non-conjugated organic entities known as radical polymers (i.e., macromolecules comprised of non-conjugated backbones and with pendant groups bearing stable radical sites) have attracted a great deal of attention for their relatively high performance in electrolyte-supported and solid-state organic electronic device applications. However, it is becoming apparent that, without fundamental advances regarding the polymer chemistry and polymer physics of open-shell macromolecules, the true potential of radical polymer systems will not be established despite the potential advantages that radical polymers could have relative to conjugated polymer systems. This effort will address these issues through the coupling of polymer synthesis with fundamental polymer physics measurements and the electrical characterization of these designer macromolecules. In particular, the PI and his group will: (1) synthesize a suite of targeted macromolecules containing select backbones, stereoregularities, and open-shell architectures; (2) evaluate the structural, thermal, and flow properties of these newly-synthesized materials; (3) correlate the electronic properties of the novel radical polymers to their chemical, thermal, and structural properties; and (4) refine the design of the macromolecules in order to elucidate their fundamental structure-property-performance relationships. In this way, this effort will provide the design principles that should allow for the radical polymers to be translated into commercially-relevant, commodity materials. This, in turn, also will allow open-shell macromolecules to play a larger part in the growing organic electronics industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plastic materials that are capable of transporting charge (e.g., electrons) are of great interest for a host of next-generation applications where low-cost, easy manufacturability, bendability, stretchability, and low-weight are needed. As such, the community has designed and evaluated many polymer design motifs that are capable of achieving performance metrics targeted for various end-use applications. The majority of this previous work has focused on a well-known category of macromolecules, conjugated polymers; however, there are still some aspects of conjugated polymer design that hinder their widespread adoption in translational efforts. As such, the work performed during this award focused on an emerging class of charge-transporting macromolecules, radical polymers. In these materials, the macromolecular backbone is not conjugated (by design) and open-shell entities are present on the pendant groups of the polymers. In this way, charge can be passed between the pendant radical sites through a series of oxidation-reduction (redox) reactions either in the solid state or in electrolyte-supported systems. Relative to their conjugated polymer counterparts, radical polymers are intriguing because: (1) their syntheses are readily amenable to large-scale production using synthetic techniques that are well-established in the commodity plastics industry; (2) they typically have weak absorption coefficients making them prime candidates for visually transparent charge-transporting materials; and (3) they serve as electronic conductors (i.e., not semiconductors) in the pristine (i.e., not doped) state. However, prior to the work of this award, the foundational structure-property-performance relationships of radical polymers, especially in solid-state applications, had not been evaluated in full.

Through the course of this award, the project was able to establish the mechanism of solid-state charge transport in radical polymers. This hinged on the idea that intimate contact between open-shell groups was required, and that a series of electronically-communicating radical moieties needed to form in the solid-state if large-scale (i.e., macroscopic) conductivity values were to be had for this system. Following this insight, a new design paradigm for radical polymers was established. That is, the project showed that synthesizing radical polymers that had glass transition temperatures that were significantly lower than the degradation temperature of the open-shell species (e.g., near-room temperature) was advantageous in terms of generating macromolecules with large electrical conductivity values. Moreover, this archetype was shown to be valid in a manner that was independent of the specific open-shell chemistry that was present on the pendant site of the macromolecules. In this way, this project was able to demonstrate the world-record electrical conductivity for a specific radical polymer at > 20 S m-1, and this places this undoped radical polymer on par with many common commercial grades of one of the most oft-used doped conjugated polymers on the market today. Thus, this project has established a clear path by which to launch a new avenue of research in this emerging subfield of polymer electronics, and it has provided an infrastructure that could reasonably launch translational of these materials to market in the not-too-distant future as well.

In addition to the outcomes associated with laboratory work, this project was instrumental in advancing key educational programs as well. The first of these efforts was the development of a massive open online course (MOOC) that covered topics associated with the physics of electronic polymers. This course had >5,300 learners enrolled in it during its lifetime with many of these learners actively engaging with others in the course community and with the instructor of the course as well. This both allowed for advanced concepts to be introduced to learners from across the globe, and it allowed for a community of folks interested in this topic to form with learners being able to engage with other interested international parties. Moreover, the technology developed during this course was translated to on-campus efforts at the award institution that allowed for an upgrade in the introductory core chemical engineering course with respect to its digital content infrastructure. In this way, the award had significant wide-ranging impacts for a large range of students. Additionally, this effort allowed for the advancement of the Purdue Project SEED Program, which is part of the American Chemical Society?s (ACS?s) Project SEED Program. This effort allows high school students from economically-disadvantaged backgrounds to engage in chemistry- and chemical engineering-based research opportunities in academia, national laboratories, and industry. Thus, this effort provided a means to engage with students interested in chemistry at a relatively early stage of their career and provided a hands-on learning opportunity that otherwise may not have been readily accessible to them during their high school education. In turn, this program has helped to broaden participation in science and engineering with an aim to create a future workforce that is diverse and well-trained. Through all of these efforts, we believe that this work has significantly improved the technology and training landscape of the United States.
